texasmonthly.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website for the Texas Monthly, a magazine that covers Texas politics, culture, and cuisine.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Texas Monthly is owned by Houston-based, private equity firm Genesis Park, whose portfolio largely consists of technology, insurance, energy, and entertainment companies. The website includes a store that features local apparel, accessories, and cooking utensils.

Texasmonthly.com generates revenue through advertisements, subscriptions, and merchandise sales.

Content

The site primarily publishes content from its affiliated magazine, including Texas political news, features about artists and musicians, sports, food, and design, as well as travel guides. Texasmonthly.com also features a section called BBQ, a podcast, and a popular advice column, the Texanist. It also issues annual Bum Steer Awards to notable Texans whom the site says “have embarrassed themselves,” and hosts an annual barbecue.

Credibility

Stories on Texasmonthly.com are generally fact-based and identify sources of information and images. Articles often link to external sources, including primary source documents. Headlines accurately reflect content.

The site does not post a corrections policy, but corrections are regularly issued, in italicized notes at the bottom of stories. The site does not have an opinion section. Some articles include the writer’s voice, but are not blatantly opinionated.

In 2018, the Columbia Journalism Review criticized the magazine for apparently making a paid promotional deal with dating app Bumble as it published a cover story about the app. The magazine denied there was any quid pro quo, but In response to the controversy, it hired an ombudsman, former Austin American-Statesman editor and Pulitzer Prize winner Rich Oppel, to help it maintain journalistic standards.

Texas Monthly has won 10 National Magazine awards, including one for feature writing in 2013 for a story about an Austin man who spent 25 years in prison, wrongfully convicted of killing his wife, before he was exonerated.

Transparency

Stories include authors’ names, with a link to their email address. The site includes a Masthead that lists executives, editors, staff writers, and contributing editors, along with their phone numbers. The outlet’s ownership is disclosed.

Advertisements are distinguishable from editorial content.

History

Texas Monthly launched in 1973. Its website was established in 1995.
